newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore oil products mixed in lacklustre trade.
newsitem.headline: Singapore oil products mixed in lacklustre trade.

text.p: The Singapore oil products closed mixed on Tuesday on conflicting market news where firmer crude prices in the West were offset by weaker Asian demand, traders said.
High sulphur fuel oil was offered down to $123.75 per tonne, about $3 lower than Monday, with some traders saying that fundamentals are under pressure as demand from China has eased.

"Activities in the Chinese market would come to a halt with the Chinese New Year lasting more than half a month (from early February) as power companies and industries would be closed," one trader said.
Gas oil was steady on prompt buying interest from the same Singapore trader who bought one cargo on Monday.
The trader bought 185,000-barrels of gas oil for loading in end January at $32.15 per barrel free-on-board Singapore from a European major, 5 cents higher than Monday's traded level.
Traders said the gas oil market is under some downward pressure due to reduced Chinese demand for February, large South Korea export availabilites and a fresh Taiwanese export tender.
The decision by the workers at South Korea's Hyundai Petrochemical to go on partial strike could add a bearish note to the naphtha market.
But so far naphtha in Singapore was not affected and rose with crude. Swaps were quoted sharply higher with January bid at $25.20 a barrel, up 40 cents from Monday's prices.
Singapore refiners indicated a healthy selling premium of around $1.00 per barrel over spot quotes but no physical trade was reported.

Gasoline firmed on the back of higher crude and naphtha in a well-supplied market. Traders assessed the gasoline/naphtha spread at $1.50 a barrel. Only a 92-octane cargo lifting Jan 22-26 was sought at $26.20 a barrel, up 20 cents from Monday's bid. --Singapore Newsroom (+65-870-3093)
